## AQ-10 vs AQ-20

Comparing the Autism Quotient (10-item) (AQ-10) and the Autism Spectrum Quotient (revised) (20 items) (AQ-20) can be a challenging task due to the volume of data and the subjective nature of this process. For psychologists and other social scientists, harmonising these two measures can be streamlined by using the Harmony software, which uses natural language processing and generative AI models to match items between the two questionnaires.

## Compare the items in AQ-10 and AQ-20

* <a href="https://harmonydata.ac.uk/app/#" target="harmonyapp">Import AQ-10 and AQ-20 into Harmony and harmonise them</a> - find similarities between the two instruments using our AI platform
* <a href="https://harmonydata.ac.uk/app/#" target="harmonyapp">Import just AQ-10 into Harmony</a> - compare AQ-10 with other instruments
* <a href="https://harmonydata.ac.uk/app/#" target="harmonyapp">Import just AQ-20 into Harmony</a> - compare AQ-20 with other instruments



Harmony facilitates the comparison of AQ-10 and AQ-20 by providing a percentage match between each item in the two instruments. This feature aids professionals in drawing accurate and objective conclusions from the data. Better yet, this can be done across different languages, which makes the AQ-10 vs AQ-20 comparison more encompassing and diverse.

Harmonizing AQ-10 vs AQ-20 has never been easier with Harmony's database, which users can utilize, or they can also add their instruments in PDF form through the website's interface. As such, the tool is a must-have for those facing the AQ-10 vs AQ-20 comparison challenge, as it simplifies what could otherwise be a complex and time-consuming process.
